name: renting hiring and hire purchase in general

children.name: landlord
children.definition: /landlady  someone who owns a building and is paid money by the people who live in it or use it:
examples: chủ nhà ( cho thuê )
▪ Our landlord has promised to fix the heating by Tuesday.
Chủ nhà của chúng tôi hứa sẽ sữa máy nấu nước vào thứ ba
▪ College accommodation offices provide lists of private landlords and landladies.
Văn phòng căn hộ trường đại học cung cấp danh sách chủ nhà
landlordnoun[ C ]OWNER chủ nhà (nhà cho thuê)
a person or organization that owns a building or an area of land and is paid by other people for the use of it
_The landlord had promised to redecorate the bedrooms before we moved in.
_Housing associations are the biggest landlords in this area.

children.name: lodger/roomer
children.definition: lodger  British someone who pays rent to live in a room in someone else’s house:
examples: người thuê nhà, người mướn trọ
▪ Are you still looking for a lodger?
▪ This young lady’s our new lodger.
have a lodger/have somebody as a lodger: có ai thuê trọ
▪ We had lodgers all through the war, most of them evacuees.
take in a lodgerstart having a lodger in your home :cho thuê trọ
▪ If you’re having trouble paying your mortgage, consider taking in a lodger or at least renting out a room.
lodgernoun[ C ] (US alsoroomer)người ở trọ
someone who pays for a place to sleep, and usually for meals, in someone else's house
_Shetakes inlodgers to make a bit of extra money.

children.name: renter
children.definition: nounUSngười thuê (nhà, đất); người cấy nộp tô
examples: someone who pays money to live in a house or an apartment that someone else owns

children.name: tenant
children.definition: someone who lives in a house, flat, or room and regularly pays money to the person who owns it:
examples: người thuê , người mướn
▪ Tenants are not allowed to keep pets.
▪ Have you found any tenants for your house yet?
tenant of
▪ Twelve tenants of the Lockwood housing complex are taking part in the lawsuit against their landlord.
tenantnoun[ C ]người thuê, người mướn (nhà, đất...)
a person who pays rent for the use of land or a building
sitting tenantnoun[ C ]người đang ở; người đang thuê
a person with a legal right to stay in a property that they are renting
_We can't sell the house because we can't get rid of the sitting tenants.

children.name: landlady
children.definition: nounOWNER bà chủ nhà (nhà cho thuê)
examples: a woman who is paid rent by people for the use of a room, building, or piece of land which she owns

children.name: leasehold
children.definition: noun quyền sử dụng bất động sản được thuê
examples: the legal right to live in or use a building, piece of land, etc. for an agreed period of time
_His familyheldthe leasehold/hadthe propertyonleasehold.
leaseholdadjective
_leasehold offices and shops
leaseholdernoun[ C ] người thuêbất động sản
the person who pays the owner of a piece of land, a building, etc. in order to be able to use it

children.name: to pay money so that you can borrow and use sth
lease
children.definition: to pay rent for the use of buildings, land, equipment, or a vehicle for a long time, especially forbusinesspurposes:
examples: thuê
▪ The Cider Press Company leases the machinery and buildings for $1000 a month.
▪ It would work out cheaper overall to lease the computers for the project.
lease something from somebody/something
▪ The building is actually owned by the government -- we’re leasing it from them.
leaseverb[ T ]cho thuê; thuê
to make a legal agreement by which money is paid in order to use land, a building, a vehicle or a piece of equipment for an agreed period of time
_The estate contains 300 new homes, about a third of which are leasedtothe council.
_[ + two objects ]It was agreed they would lease the flattohim/lease him the flat.

children.name: rent
children.definition: /rent/  to pay a particular amount of moneyregularlyfor the use of a house, office, telephone etc over aperiod of months or years:
examples: thuê ( và trả tiền hàng tháng )
▪ Many young couples rent an apartment until they’ve saved enough money to buy a house.
▪ I can’t afford to rent an office in this part of town.
▪ Do you own your home or are you renting?
rent something from somebody/something
▪ Did you know you can rent a fax machine from the telephone company?
rented[adjective]
▪ We’ve lived in rented accommodation since we were married so we’re desperate to get our own place.
rentverbPAY TO USE
[ T ] to pay a fixed amount of money for the use of a room, house, car, television, etc
_I rented a carfroma garage so that I could get about.
_[ + two objects ]The old lady rented us her spare bedroomfor£55 a week.
_My Dad has a cottage which he rents(out) totourists.

children.name: rent / hire
children.definition: renthire  thuê ( 1 thời gian ngắn )
examples: to pay money to a company to use a car, or a piece of equipment or clothing for a period of days or hours:
▪ Should we rent a video tonight?
▪ Let’s hire a car for the weekend and go and visit Jenny and Steve.
▪ You rented a tuxedo for two hundred dollars? Are you crazy?
hire/rent sth from sb/sth
▪ When she got to Dallas she rented a Ford convertible from the Avis desk.
rentedalsohiredBritish [adjective]
▪ No, the skis aren’t mine. They’re hired.
▪ The bride arrived at the church in a rented limousine.
hireverb[ T ]UK( hire something from somebody) thuê mướn
(USrent) to pay to use something for a short period
_How much would it cost to hire a car for a fortnight?
_You could always hire a dress for the ball if you can't afford to buy one.

children.name: charter
children.definition: thuê ( máy bay, thuyền )
examples: charter/ˈtʃɑːʳtəʳ/ [transitive verb] to pay money to a company for the use of one of theirplanesorships:
▪ A group of journalists chartered an airplane to fly them to Addis Ababa.
▪ International Aid Agencies have chartered ships to transport supplies to the disaster area.
charterverb[ T ]RENTthuê (máy bay...) vì một mục đích nào đó
to rent a vehicle, especially an aircraft, for a special use and not as part of a regular service
_They've chartered a plane to take delegates to the conference.

children.name: lease
children.definition: to allow acompany,organizationetc to use buildings, land, or equipment for afixedperiodof time, in exchange for money:
examples: cho thuê
lease something to somebody
▪ The company plans to sell or lease its remaining stores to other supermarkets.
▪ The aircraft had been leased to a Nigerian airline.
lease somebody something
▪ Internet start-ups are being helped by companies willing to lease them Web servers and space.
leaseverb[ T ]cho thuê; thuê
to make a legal agreement by which money is paid in order to use land, a building, a vehicle or a piece of equipment for an agreed period of time
_The estate contains 300 new homes, about a third of which are leasedtothe council.
_[ + two objects ]It was agreed they would lease the flattohim/lease him the flat.

children.name: rent out
children.definition: alsorent American   to allow someone to use a house, piece of land, vehicleetcthat belongs to you, in exchange for money:

children.name: cho thuê
examples: ▪ We rent cars by the hour, to save you money.
▪ Some caterers will rent equipment and supplies for parties at a reasonable cost.

children.name: rent something (out) to somebody
examples: ▪ I’m thinking of renting the upstairs rooms to students.
▪ The field at the back of the house is rented out to a local farmer.

children.name: rent somebody something
examples: ▪ We can rent you a luxury apartment for the duration of your stay.
▪ I’m sorry, I’ve had an accident in the car you rented me this morning.

children.name: rent (out) something (to somebody)
examples: ▪ Mike raised some cash by renting out the two small workshops to local craftsmen.

children.name: let X/ rent
children.definition: letBritish /rentAmerican /let, rent/  to allow someone to use aroom,house, orofficein exchange for money:
examples: cho thuê
let/rent something to somebody
▪ We usually rent our house to someone over the long vacation.
▪ 200,00 sq ft of land was let to a local firm.
let/rent out something
British
▪ We even had to rent out the garage to make ends meet.
▪ The company owns about 170 cottages in Britain, which it lets out to tourists.
let/rent something out
▪ Many residents hoped to rent their houses out during the Games.
To LetBritish/For RentAmericanwrittenon a sign to show that a room, house, or office is empty and can be rented
▪ Nellie’s house had a ‘To Let’ sign in the window.
letverbletting,let,letRENTcho thuê
[ T ]mainlyUK(mainly USrent) to allow your house or land to belived in or used by someone else in exchange for a regular payment
_They are letting their house(out)for the summer.
_He's let his flattoa young couple.
_She has a roomtolet in her house.
rentverbPAY TO USE
[ T ] to receive a fixed amount of money for the use of a room, house, car, television, etc
_I rented a carfroma garage so that I could get about.
_[ + two objects ]The old lady rented us her spare bedroomfor£55 a week.
_My Dad has a cottage which he rents(out) totourists.

children.name: hire out
children.definition: British to allow someone to use something such as a vehicle or clothes for ashortperiodof time, in exchange for money:
examples: cho thuê ( ngắn hạn )
hire out something
▪ They were partners in a business which hired out photocopiers.
▪ Do you hire out golf clubs here?
hire something/it/them out
▪ Brooke bought a Rolls Royce and started hiring it out for special occasions.
hiresth/sboutphrasal verb[ M ]
to allow someone to use something or someone temporarily in exchange for money
_How much do you charge for hiring out a bicycle for a week?
_[ R ]He's decided to go freelance and hire himselfout as a technical writer.

children.name: amount of money you pay to use sth
rent
children.definition: /rent/  the amount of money that you pay to live in or use a place that you do not own:
examples: tiền thuê (nhà,đất)
pay rent
trả tiền thuê
▪ She pays £350 a month rent for a one-bedroomed apartment.
high/low rent
Giá thuê cao/thấp
▪ Office rents are highest in the city centre.
put up the rent/raise the rentincrease it
tăng tiền thuê
▪ If my landlord raises the rent again, I’ll have to look for somewhere smaller.
rentnounPAYMENT
[ C or U ] a fixed amount of money that you pay regularly for the use of a room, house, car, television, etc. that someone else owns
_I pay a higher rent/more rent than the other tenants because my room is bigger.
_Rents here are ridiculouslyhigh/low.

children.name: rental
children.definition: the amount of money that you pay to use a car, television, tools etc over a period of time:
examples: tiền thuê (xe, TV, đồ đạc,...)
▪ The rental on the TV includes maintenance and repairs.
car/television/video etc rental
tiền thuê xe/TV/băng đĩa
▪ Car rental is $200 a week and you need a clean driving licence.
rentalnoun[ C or U ]
an arrangement to rent something, or the amount of money that you pay to rent something
_Property rental is quite expensive here.
_Video and television rentals have decreased this year.
_a car rentalcompany

children.name: lease
children.definition: noun hợp đồng cho thuê (bất động sản)

children.name: a legal agreement in which you pay money in order to use a building, piece of land, vehicle, etc. for a period
examples: _He has the flatona long lease.
_The lease runs out/expires in two years' time.
_Wesigneda three-year lease when we moved into the house.

children.name: for rent
children.definition: available to be rented
examples: ▪ Vicky put the house up for rent a month ago, but changed her mind the next day.
for rent
offered by the owner for someone else to use in exchange for money

children.name: tenancy
children.definition: nounthời gian thuê, thời gian mướn, thời gian lĩnh canh
examples: [ C ] the period of time for which you have the right to use a building or piece of land
a two-year tenancy

children.name: sublet
children.definition: verbsubletting,sublet,subletcho thuê lại; cho thầu lại

children.name: to allow someone to rent all or part of a house or other building which you are renting from someone else
examples: _Our rental contract states that we are not allowed to sublet the house.

children.name: rental
children.definition: nounhợp đồng thuê

children.name: an arrangement to rent something
examples: _Property rental is quite expensive here.
_Video and television rentals have decreased this year.

children.name: rented
children.definition: adjective
examples: describes something that yourent(= pay to use)
_rentedaccommodation

children.name: tenancy
children.definition: noun
examples: [ C or U ] the right to use land or live in a building in exchange for rent

children.name: subtenant
children.definition: nounngười thuê lại, người mướn lại
examples: a person who rents a building from someone who is renting it from the owner

children.name: rent-free
children.definition: adjective,adverbkhông mất tiền thuê
examples: If a house is rent-free or if you are living or staying rent-free, the owner is not asking forpayment.

children.name: hired
children.definition: adjectiveUKthuê; để cho thuê

children.name: _a hired car
examples: _The police believe he was killed by a hired assassin.

children.name: chartered
children.definition: adjectiveRENTED
examples: [ before noun ] rented for a particular purpose
_a small chartered plane
_They spent their annual holiday on a chartered yacht in theCaribbean.

children.name: on the never-never
children.definition: trảgóp

children.name: using a system of payment in which part of the cost of something is paid immediately and then small regular payments are made until the debt is reduced to nothing
examples: _I don't likebuyingthings on the never-never because they charge you such a lot in interest.

children.name: installment plan
children.definition: nounsự mua trả góp (người mua trả tiền dần dần, có quyền sử dụng ngay và trở thành chủ nhân của món hàngsau khi trả một số lần nhất định)
examples: US forhire purchase

children.name: hire purchase
children.definition: nounUK(abbreviationHP,USinstallment plan)sự mua trả góp (người mua trả tiền dần dần, có quyền sử dụng ngay và trở thành chủ nhân của món hàngsau khi trả một số lần nhất định)
examples: a method of paying for something in which the buyer payspart of the cost
immediately and then makes small regular payments until the debt is completely paid
HPnoun[ U ]
UK abbreviation forhire purchase
_We bought our televisiononHP.
